edu.stanford.cfuller.imageanalysistools.image

Class PixelData

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.stanford.cfuller.imageanalysistools.image.PixelData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ImagePlusPixelData, LargePixelData

    public class PixelData
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Holds image pixel data in a type-independent manner; handles conversion to the appropriate number format for the data being stored to disk.

    This implementation is currently rather memory inefficient in order to be able to store any image format in a common way; large images should use LargePixelData, which will cache all but the current plane in use to disk, as needed.

    It is recommended that PixelData objects be constructed with a PixelDataFactory, which will choose whether to use the in-memory or disk-using version depending on the size of the image.

    Author:
    Colin J. Fuller
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • PixelData

        protected PixelData()

      • PixelData

        public PixelData(ImageCoordinate sizes,
         int data_type,
         java.lang.String dimensionOrder)
        Constructs a new pixeldata object using an ImageCoordinate to specify the size of the pixeldata.
        Parameters:
        sizes - An ImageCoordinate that specifies the size of the pixeldata in all 5 (XYZCT) dimensions.
        data_type - An integer that specifies the numeric type of the on-disk representation of this data; valid values are from FormatTools
        dimensionOrder - A string made up of the characters "XYZCT" in any order that specifies the order of the dimensions in the on-disk representation.

      • PixelData

        public PixelData(int size_x,
         int size_y,
         int size_z,
         int size_c,
         int size_t,
         int data_type,
         java.lang.String dimensionOrder)
        Convenience constructor for creating a PixelData object with individual dimension sizes instead of the sizes lumped into an ImageCoordinate.
        Parameters:
        size_x - Size of the pixel data in the X-dimension.
        size_y - Size of the pixel data in the Y-dimension.
        size_z - Size of the pixel data in the Z-dimension.
        size_c - Size of the pixel data in the C-dimension.
        size_t - Size of the pixel data in the T-dimension.
        data_type - An integer that specifies the numeric type of the on-disk representation of this data; valid values are from FormatTools
        dimensionOrder - A string made up of the characters "XYZCT" in any order that specifies the order of the dimensions in the on-disk representation.

    • Method Detail

      • init

        protected void init(int size_x,
        int size_y,
        int size_z,
        int size_c,
        int size_t,
        java.lang.String dimensionOrder)
        Initializes the internals of the PixelData object using the specified parameters.
        Parameters:
        size_x - The size of the PixelData in the x-dimension (in pixels).
        size_y - The size of the PixelData in the y-dimension (in pixels).
        size_z - The size of the PixelData in the z-dimension (in pixels).
        size_c - The size of the PixelData in the c-dimension (in pixels).
        size_t - The size of the PixelData in the t-dimension (in pixels).
        dimensionOrder - A string containing the 5 characters "XYZCT" in some order specifying the order in which the dimensions are stored in the underlying byte representation.

      • hasZ

        public boolean hasZ()
        Queries whether the PixelData object has a non-singleton Z dimension.
        Returns:
        true if the Z-dimension size is greater than 1, false otherwise.

      • hasT

        public boolean hasT()
        Queries whether the PixelData object has a non-singleton T dimension.
        Returns:
        true if the T-dimension size is greater than 1, false otherwise.

      • hasC

        public boolean hasC()
        Queries whether the PixelData object has a non-singleton C dimension.
        Returns:
        true if the C-dimension size is greater than 1, false otherwise.

      • setBytes

        public void setBytes(byte[] pixelBytes)
        Sets the raw byte representation of the pixel data to the specified array.

        Pixel values should be represented by the numeric type, byte order, and dimension order specified when initializing the PixelData. This will not be checked for the correct format.

        The internal numerical representation of the pixel data will be updated immediately, and the data in the specified byte array will replace any existing data.

        Parameters:
        pixelBytes - A byte array containing the new pixel data.

      • getBytes

        public byte[] getBytes()
        Gets the raw byte representation of the pixel data.

        Pixel values will be represented using the numeric type, byte order, and dimension order specified on initializing the PixelData.

        Calling this function will encode the byte array data from the internal numerical representation, so in particular, if the byte data was previously set using setBytes(byte[]), and then changes were made using setPixel(int, int, int, int, int, float), for example, these changes will be reflected, and this will not return the same byte data originally passed in.

        Returns:
        A byte array containing the pixel data encoded in the specified format.

      • getNumPlanes

        public int getNumPlanes()
        Gets the number of planes in the image.

        A plane is defined as the extent of the PixelData in the x-y direction, so the number of planes is the sizes of all dimensions besides X and Y multiplied together.

        Returns:
        The number of planes in the PixelData.

      • getPlaneSizeInBytes

        protected int getPlaneSizeInBytes()
        Gets the number of bytes needed to store a single X-Y image plane in the underlying byte representation.
        Returns:
        The number of bytes for a single plane.

      • getPlane

        public byte[] getPlane(int index)
                throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Get a single plane of the image formatted as a raw byte array.

        A plane is defined as the extend of the PixelData in the x-y direction, so a single plane will reflect a single (Z,C,T) coordinate.

        Note that this definition requires that the dimension order of the PixelData start with "XY". If the dimension order were "ZCXYT" or something similarly strange, then this method would not work correctly.

        The byte array will be encoded as when calling getBytes().

        The planes are indexed according to the dimension order specified when initializing the PixelData.

        Parameters:
        index - The index of the plane to return in the specified dimension order.
        Returns:
        A byte array holding the requested plane encoded in the specified format.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the dimension order does not start with XY or YX.

      • getPixel

        public float getPixel(int x,
             int y,
             int z,
             int c,
             int t)
        Gets the value of a single pixel at the specified coordinates.

        Note that the parameters are passed in the order x,y,z,c,t regardless of the ordering in the underlying byte array representation and will be converted to the correct ordering automatically. (All coordinates are zero-indexed.)

        Parameters:
        x - The x-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        y - The y-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        z - The z-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        c - The c-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        t - The t-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        Returns:
        The value of the PixelData at the specified coordinates, as a float.

      • setPixel

        public void setPixel(int x,
            int y,
            int z,
            int c,
            int t,
            float value)
        Gets the value of a single pixel at the specified coordinates.

        Note that the parameters are passed in the order x,y,z,c,t regardless of the ordering in the underlying byte array representation and will be converted to the correct ordering automatically.

        Likewise, though the value is passed as a float, it will be converted automatically to the underlying byte representation in the correct format. This may lead to the truncation of the passed float value when retrieving the byte array representation. However, the float passed in can still be retreived without truncation by calling getPixel(int, int, int, int, int).

        (All coordinates are zero-indexed.)

        Parameters:
        x - The x-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        y - The y-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        z - The z-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        c - The c-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        t - The t-coordinate of the pixel to return.
        value - The value to which the pixel at the specified coordinates will be set.

      • getDataType

        public int getDataType()
        Gets the data type used for the underlying byte array representation.

        The meanings of the integers returned are specified as constants in FormatTools.

        Returns:
        An integer corresponding to the format of the underlying byte representation of the data.

      • getLociDataType

        public int getLociDataType()
        Deprecated. Use getDataType() instead.
        Gets the data type used for the underlying byte array representation.

        The meanings of the integers returned are specified as constants in FormatTools.

        Returns:
        An integer corresponding to the format of the underlying byte representation of the data.

      • updateConvertedPixelsFromBytes

        protected void updateConvertedPixelsFromBytes()
        Reads the underlying byte array using the specified byte order, dimension order, and data format and stores it as an array of floats, which is accessed by users of this class.

      • updateBytesFromConvertedPixels

        protected void updateBytesFromConvertedPixels()
        Converts the array of floats used for access by users of this class back to a byte array representation (suitable for writing to disk) according to the stored byte order, dimension order, and data type.

      • getSizeZ

        public int getSizeZ()
        Gets the size of the z-dimension of the PixelData.
        Returns:
        The size of the z-dimension (in pixels, or equivalently, planes).

      • getSizeC

        public int getSizeC()
        Gets the size of the c-dimension of the PixelData.
        Returns:
        The size of the c-dimension (in pixels, or equivalently, color channels).

      • getSizeT

        public int getSizeT()
        Gets the size of the t-dimension of the PixelData.
        Returns:
        The size of the t-dimension (in pixels, or equivalently, timepoints).

      • getDimensionOrder

        public java.lang.String getDimensionOrder()
        Gets the dimension order of the underlying byte representation of the PixelData as a string.

        An example string for one particular dimension order is "XYZCT"

        Returns:
        A String containing one character for each dimension specifying the dimension order.

      • setByteOrder

        public void setByteOrder(java.nio.ByteOrder b)
        Sets the byte order of the underlying byte array representation to one of the constants specified in ByteOrder
        Parameters:
        b - The ByteOrder constant to which the byte order of the PixelData will be set.

      • getByteOrder

        public java.nio.ByteOrder getByteOrder()
        Gets the byte order of the underlying byte array representation of the data, as one of the constants specified in ByteOrder.
        Returns:
        The ByteOrder constant corresponding to the byte order of the underlying byte array representation of the data.

      • toImagePlus

        public ij.ImagePlus toImagePlus()
        Returns an ImagePlus representation of the data contained in this PixelData.

        This may return null if an ImagePlus is not involved in the representation of the PixelData.

        Returns:
        An ImagePlus representation of the PixelData, or null.
